keyTakeAways: Richard Kenneth Djerf was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 killing of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix.
Djerf was convicted of sexually assaulting and murdering Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, Rochelle Luna (18), and Damien Luna (5), after blaming a family member for a prior theft.
The execution marked Arizona’s second execution of the year and the 39th execution in 2025, with four in the U.S. during the week.
Djerf had been in prison for over 29 years and declined to seek clemency, though he issued a statement acknowledging the crimes and apologizing.
The execution process took about 10 minutes, with IV placement taking multiple attempts due to poor vein conditions, raising concerns about compliance with execution timing standards.
Arizona has faced criticism in the past for botched executions and delays, including a 2014 incident involving Joseph Wood, which led to a pause in executions from 2014 to 2022.
The state has paused executions twice since 2014 due to procedural and ethical concerns, and resumed in 2022 after reforms.
The 2024 review of execution protocols ended when Governor Katie Hobbs dismissed a federal magistrate, and new procedures were adopted.
The execution of Djerf increased the number of prisoners on Arizona’s death row to 107.
Five more executions are scheduled in the U.S. this year, including two in Florida and one each in Alabama, Oklahoma, and Tennessee.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Richard Kenneth Djerf, 55, was executed in Arizona on October 18, 2025, for the 1993 murder of four members of the Luna family in Phoenix — Albert Luna Sr., Patricia Luna, their daughter Rochelle Luna, and son Damien Luna. Prosecutors allege Djerf, driven by a false belief that Albert Luna Jr. stole from him, committed the killings in an act of revenge, sexually assaulting Rochelle and fatally attacking the others. The execution, Arizona’s second of the year and 39th of 2025, took about 10 minutes, with complications in IV placement due to poor vein conditions. The state has faced repeated criticism and pauses in executions since 2014 due to botched procedures and ethical concerns, including a 2014 incident involving Joseph Wood. After a 2023 review and policy changes, executions resumed in 2022. Djerf had previously issued a public apology and acknowledged the crimes, but declined clemency. With this execution, Arizona’s death row now has 107 prisoners. The event reflects ongoing national debates about the use of capital punishment, with five more executions scheduled across the U.S. in 2025.
